H0.text: The infected animals do not show symptoms, which explains why diseases transmitted through their bites are not considered contagious diseases.

H1.text: The person in direct contact is the only one infected in diseases transmitted through the bites of infected animals, which is why they are not considered contagious diseases.

H2.text: Humans do not become sick from animal diseases, which is why diseases transmitted through bites of infected animals are not considered contagious.

H3.text: The diseases are treatable with antibiotics is the reason why diseases transmitted through the bites of infected animals are not considered contagious diseases.

A4.text: Zoonotic diseases generally refer to diseases of animal origin in which direct or vector mediated animal-to-human transmission is the usual source of human infection. Animal populations are the principal reservoir of the pathogen and horizontal infection in humans is rare.

A5.text: Infected animals are exceptionally aggressive, may attack without provocation, and exhibit otherwise uncharacteristic behavior.

A6.text: There are only a small number of recorded cases of human-to-human transmission of rabies, and all occurred through organ transplants.

A9.text: Rabies is a viral infection spread that is transmitted through exposure to the saliva or brain tissue of an infected animal. The saliva of the infected animal enters a wound or mucous membrane.

A10.text: Humans do not usually act as primary vectors for zoonotic diseases; however, they contribute to indirect transmission via human travel or trade aiding the spread of vector-borne diseases.

A11.text: Diseases that can be transmitted by direct contact are called contagious.
